issue.title: Consider public use of Bref\Runtime\LambdaRuntime for containers who does not inherit from bref/php-?? images
issue.body:
> **TL;TR** Consider public use of `Bref\Runtime\LambdaRuntime` for containers who does not inherit from `bref/php-??` images

After check all those announcements around the possibility of use custom container images for Lambda, I've feel those examples are unnecessary complicated.

All those examples assume you should inherit from AWS Lamda images (public.ecr.aws/lambda/*) when the only thing those images provide is the Lambda RIE used for local development/testing.

I have wrote an small example (https://github.com/Maks3w/php-lambda-example) showing how it could be possible base your custom containers in the official PHP images and only install Lambda RIE for development.

I think this approach is more simple than others where you have to deal with the installation of PHP or you have more PHP extensions than you really need.

In fact the example shows there is less room for `bref` for this kind of deployment. However there is still a need for manage the Lambda payloads received and the return of the results. These things are well implemented by *bref* in [`Bref\Runtime\LambdaRuntime`](https://github.com/brefphp/bref/blob/master/src/Runtime/LambdaRuntime.php)
but this class is tagged as `@internal` what it means no forward guaranteed compatibility.

It could be possible to open `Bref\Runtime\LambdaRuntime` as a public class?

issue.title: Consider public use of Bref\Runtime\LambdaRuntime for containers who does not inherit from bref/php-?? images
issue.body:
> **TL;TR** Consider public use of `Bref\Runtime\LambdaRuntime` for containers who does not inherit from `bref/php-??` images

After check all those announcements around the possibility of use custom container images for Lambda, I've feel those examples are unnecessary complicated.

All those examples assume you should inherit from AWS Lamda images (public.ecr.aws/lambda/*) when the only thing those images provide is the Lambda RIE used for local development/testing.

I have wrote an small example (https://github.com/Maks3w/php-lambda-example) showing how it could be possible base your custom containers in the official PHP images and only install Lambda RIE for development.

I think this approach is more simple than others where you have to deal with the installation of PHP or you have more PHP extensions than you really need.

In fact the example shows there is less room for `bref` for this kind of deployment. However there is still a need for manage the Lambda payloads received and the return of the results. These things are well implemented by *bref* in [`Bref\Runtime\LambdaRuntime`](https://github.com/brefphp/bref/blob/master/src/Runtime/LambdaRuntime.php)
but this class is tagged as `@internal` what it means no forward guaranteed compatibility.

It could be possible to open `Bref\Runtime\LambdaRuntime` as a public class?

comment.body:
Hey everyone! I haven't forgotten about this :) 

In Bref 2, this will now be possible, and be actually simpler. The 3 different runtimes (fpm, function and console) now have each a public API, though slightly different from what was discussed here (i.e. that's what I mean by simpler).

### FPM

I actually moved the FPM runtime to a separate repository (https://github.com/brefphp/php-fpm-runtime), and its main entrypoint (bootstrap.php) is now a public API.

In short, [run `vendor/bref/php-fpm-runtime/src/bootstrap.php`](https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers/blob/5e248826993c467d539ff55498ed9291b16d7f66/layers/fpm/bootstrap.sh#L12).

### Function

Require `bref/bref` and [run `Bref\FunctionRuntime\Main::run()`](https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers/blob/5e248826993c467d539ff55498ed9291b16d7f66/layers/function/bootstrap.php#L17).

### Function

Require `bref/bref` and [run `Bref\ConsoleRuntime\Main::run()`](https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers/blob/5e248826993c467d539ff55498ed9291b16d7f66/layers/console/bref/bootstrap.php#L5).

🤦

To answer your question, yes we copy a lot of libs: https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers/blob/main/php-80/cpu-x86.Dockerfile#L41 (FYI `/bref/lib` becomes `/opt/lib` in these images)

But you made me realize that we copy them to `/opt/lib` (in Bref 2 I mean). All is good, sorry ^^

issue.title: Bref 2.0
issue.body:
Hey @Nyholm!

As I work on Bref v2, I started testing the impact on the extra extensions. I think it _should_ be minimal.

So far I've been able to build redis, decimal, and ds by just replacing:

```diff
- FROM bref/build-php-$PHP_VERSION:1.7.4 AS ext
+ FROM --platform=linux/amd64 bref/build-php-$PHP_VERSION:latest AS ext
```

Note: I used `latest` so that it uses the local image I built from https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers Eventually you'll be able to use a real version like 2.0.0 or something similar.

The main change is to force using the x86 platform, else when building on M1 (for example) it tries to pick up the ARM images.

Bref v2 will also contain ARM images, I'm not sure if that implies also building extensions on ARM specifically, but I guess it might be the case. Not sure if this is something you want to tackle outright.

comment.body:
> @mnapoli as we use Makefiles, looks like a better option to set DOCKER_DEFAULT_PLATFORM env var for example than putting a --platform=linux/amd64 option into the FROM instruction of Dockerfiles.

Makes sense to me, not sure if you have an opinion on this @Nyholm.

TBH I don't have a strong opinion on this, I don't know much better than you on this.

I created the branch: https://github.com/brefphp/extra-php-extensions/tree/v2

Do you think I should also move the "lib" directory in the base Bref images? I'm confused why I haven't faced this problem there 🤔

issue.title: Bref 2.0: rewritten runtimes
issue.body:
This issue is about one big change in Bref 2.0: new (rewritten) runtimes. This issue only covers this change.

## Background

@deleugpn worked a lot on the runtimes/layers, and started working on #1078 to completely refactor how they are built.

The PR stalled earlier this year, I am picking it back up and finishing the changes for Bref 2.0. Feel free to read the PR, but it doesn't reflect 100% what we have now.

## Goals

1. Easier to maintain and contribute
2. #1043 (thanks to the above)
3. Improve Bref compatibility with Terraform, AWS CDK, Pulumi…
4. Allow newcomers to test Bref in the AWS console without installing it

Not a direct goal, but a pleasant side-effect: makes it easier for advanced users to create their own runtime/customize the existing runtimes.

## User impact

Everything will continue to work like in v1 (there will just be more "possibilities"), no code changes should be necessary.

It will be a new major version because we are changing the way PHP is compiled, and it might impact extra layers or extensions. The goal is to be safe.

## Details

### 1. Easier to maintain and contribute

How:

- Install PHP from a distribution instead of compiling it.
- The point above also led to much simpler and faster scripts.
- Added automated tests for the runtimes.
- Added commands so contributors can easily build, test, and upload layers.
- Refactorings/code reorganization.

The work in progress is in this repository: https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers 
This repository contains all the git history of Bref (`runtime/` directory) and #1043 on top of it. However newer commits are not included (too hard to rebase everything).

Trade-offs:

- We install PHP from [Remi Collet's repository](https://blog.remirepo.net/en): this is a trusted, reliable and **up-to-date** repository from a core PHP contributor (more [details here](https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers#installing-php-from-a-distribution)), but we become dependent on a 3rd party.
- v2 layers will probably be published to a new AWS account, to avoid any possible error for Bref v1 users that want to stay on this version.


### 2. Add Graviton/ARM support (#1043)

How:

- Thanks to the simplification, adding Graviton support becomes easier.
- Remi doesn't distribute arm builds, we install PHP from `amazon-linux-extras`.

Trade-offs:

- `amazon-linux-extras` is 5 months behind PHP's schedule and doesn't support PHP 8.1 yet.

### 3. Improve Bref compatibility with Terraform, AWS CDK, Pulumi…

How:

- Break the current coupling between layers and Bref's code: that will make upgrading layers decoupled from the Bref version.
- Make exposing Bref layers (layers.json) in more format (e.g. NPM package) easier to do, because it's decoupled to Bref's codebase.

Want to see what this looks like? Here's an example with the "function" runtime:

- [`bootstrap.sh`](https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers/blob/9d96433885a32422a04af8773282cbe216bd1fb8/layers/function/bootstrap.sh) is the Lambda entrypoint, it runs `bootstrap.php`
- [`bootstrap.php`](https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers/blob/9d96433885a32422a04af8773282cbe216bd1fb8/layers/function/bootstrap.php) has no dependencies, it runs Bref's function runtime from the user's vendor directory
- Bref's function runtime should be installed by Bref users (will be required by bref/bref, so it's transparent), here is the repo: https://github.com/brefphp/php-runtime

With the solution described above, the layer is 100% decoupled from Bref's codebase. It is possible to upgrade layers and Bref separately.

Trade-offs:

- Possibly a more complex codebase (e.g. multi-repo) for maintainers.
- Requires more automation/orchestration of Bref releases.
- So far I had to remove the feature "[separate vendor directory](https://bref.sh/docs/environment/php.html#separate-vendor-folder)" because it made things much harder. I don't think this feature is used a lot, and it is poorly maintained (community-contributed), source of a lot of frustration. I'm fine dropping it.

### 4. Allow newcomers to test Bref in the AWS console without installing it

How:

- FPM layers become self-contained and do not require the Bref codebase.

Indeed, the user codebase runs in FPM and is not coupled to the Bref API (when using the FPM layer). That means we can create an FPM layer that contains all the code it needs to run. Users can create an empty Lambda function with a single `index.php` and things will work.

Prototype of externalizing the FPM runtime: https://github.com/brefphp/php-fpm-runtime (the FPM layer contains this code, Bref users do not have to install it anymore).

Trade-offs:

- Move from a monolithic codebase (one version, one repo) to multiple repositories.

----

Feedback is welcome.

I am currently building layers and will post layers ARNs soon if you want to test things out and participate.

comment.body:
Getting close to finishing!

Today I worked on the dev images and I have found an interesting approach that could simplify local development. Curious to get your feedback: https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers/pull/38

pull_request.title: Bref 2 dev images
pull_request.body: While porting Bref 1 "dev" images to Bref 2, I was looking at how to improve the DX for users. I think I managed to find an interesting result that combines all use cases into a single "dev" image that works out of the box, with xdebug and blackfire. I recorded a video to show it in more details if you are interested: https://youtu.be/0PnreyR8c58 If you don't have time for the video, here's a quick example: ### Bref v1 ```yaml services: web: image: bref/fpm-dev-gateway ports: - '8000:80' volumes: - .:/var/task depends_on: - php environment: HANDLER: public/index.php DOCUMENT_ROOT: public app: image: bref/php-80-fpm-dev volumes: - .:/var/task console: image: bref/php-80 volumes: - .:/var/task entrypoint: php ``` ### Bref v2 ```yaml services: app: image: bref/php-80-fpm-dev ports: [ '8000:8000' ] volumes: - .:/var/task environment: HANDLER: public/index.php DOCUMENT_ROOT: public ```

pull_request.title: Remove `@internal` tags on classes that now become public API
pull_request.body:
Fix #1291

In previous open-source projects, I never thought twice about making classes `@internal`. That meant that any code I wrote for internal purposes was instantly part of the public API of the package.

Over the years, this caused me a lot of issues because I had to keep backward compatibility for that code. Even though (very likely) nobody was actually using it. This made maintenance and refactorings much harder.

When I worked on Bref, I added the `@internal` tag by default on all code I wrote that wasn't meant to be used by end users.

Now that we have a few years of experience, I can see that some of this code is very stable (no need to refactor it), and could actually be useful outside of Bref.

So let's open it up! This PR removes a lot of `@internal` tags and makes this internal code part of the public API. It will be maintained and free of breaking changes in minor versions.

When I worked on Bref, I added the `@internal` tag by default on all code I wrote that wasn't meant to be used by end users.

Now that we have a few years of experience, I can see that some of this code is very stable (no need to refactor it), and could actually be useful outside of Bref.

So let's open it up! This PR removes a lot of `@internal` tags and makes this internal code part of the public API. It will be maintained and free of breaking changes in minor versions.

issue.title: Bref 2.0
issue.body:
Hey @Nyholm!

As I work on Bref v2, I started testing the impact on the extra extensions. I think it _should_ be minimal.

So far I've been able to build redis, decimal, and ds by just replacing:

```diff
- FROM bref/build-php-$PHP_VERSION:1.7.4 AS ext
+ FROM --platform=linux/amd64 bref/build-php-$PHP_VERSION:latest AS ext
```

Note: I used `latest` so that it uses the local image I built from https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers Eventually you'll be able to use a real version like 2.0.0 or something similar.

The main change is to force using the x86 platform, else when building on M1 (for example) it tries to pick up the ARM images.

Bref v2 will also contain ARM images, I'm not sure if that implies also building extensions on ARM specifically, but I guess it might be the case. Not sure if this is something you want to tackle outright.

pull_request.title: [Proposal] Runtime changes
pull_request.body:
This pull request is an ongoing work with an attempt to drastically change the Runtime system.

### Why?

It's an attempt to make things easier to change. Although it was triggered by AWS releasing Graviton support on Lambda, this pull request isn't entirely about supporting Graviton, but in fact making it easier and more accessible to build, test and reproduce the layers provided by Bref.

### What are the changes?

- The expected result is ann easier to reproduce system by leveraging primarily Docker and Docker Compose.
- Instead of compiling PHP, we delegate that work to reliable sources like Remi Collect ([recommendation](https://twitter.com/peter_kokot/status/1444642270976921602))
- Simplify the process to become more accessible for us PHP Developers
- ~Steal~ Take inspiration from the folks at Vercel ([Source](https://github.com/juicyfx/libphp/blob/master/libs/amazon-linux-2-v80/Makefile#L53))

#### What does it mean for new PHP releases?

Although compiling PHP means we're in control of compiling point releases as soon as they come, remi-collect has a great track record of releasing new version on the same day (or even the day before) a new version is announced on the PHP internal list. The downside is that Remi doesn't provide aarch64 support, which means we would need to rely on `amazon-linux-extras` for Graviton support. Currently Amazon only provides PHP 8.0.8 (about 4 months behind). My take is that it's better to provide delayed aarch64 than not provide at all or provide it using emulators or in a hard-to-maintain process. Given that Apple is pushing arm64 with the new M1 laptops and AWS is pushing it via Graviton support, it's a matter of time until there's better release cycle around arm64.

### How does it work?

The project structure is divided into `common`, `phpxx`, `tests` and the root folder.

The `common` folder contains files for the fpm layer, function layer and the scripts for publishing the layers. The FPM and Function layers are built by using `composer install` and generating a `vendor` folder that will be embedded and available inside the Lambda Layer.

The `php74`, `php80` and `php81` folders are suppose to be incredibly identical and easy to test and replicate. Each PHP Folder has it's own Makefile so that contributors can `make function` and publish their own layer in their own account. This allows for easy testing for layers modifications.

The `tests` folder contains assertions that will be executed inside the container of each layer so that we can "prove" that the system works.

Finally, the root folder contains a Makefile and a docker-compose file that allows for parallelization of building all layers / php versions and publishing them on all regions.

Special thanks to [Aran Reeks](https://twitter.com/AranReeks/status/1445106462443937792?t=L4IeLGy1zpN855BfJe4LeQ&s=19) for teaching me about `ldd` to show linked libraries for the php binary and its extensions.

### What is the `/opt/bref-internal-src` folder?

This is an attempt to make PHP on Lambda easier to onboard and test. It allows to replicate the experience of other Runtime. You go to the AWS Console, create a new Function, attach Bref's layer to it, write a `hello.php` file and run it. No need for `composer` or `serverless`. Just plain old PHP. It greatly improves the User Experience when testing things out.

### How can I test this myself?

The biggest motivation for this pull request is to make it easier for anyone/everyone build their own layer so that you can test things out yourself. Making it more reproducible / accessible will help contributors changing the layer to test things. Here are the steps:

```
git clone git@github.com:brefphp/bref.git
cd bref
git checkout runtime
cd runtime
cd php81

# Modify the Makefile with your AWS credentials

# Run the project tests
make test 

# Publish your own `function` layer
make function

# Publish your own `fpm` layer
make fpm
```

These steps will publish a new layer into your own AWS Account so that you can test them.

### Comparison

```
bref/php-81                             latest      127c04144153   333MB
bref/x86-php81-function                 latest      c46d3edc8846   361MB

bref/php-80                             latest      1300e903c67e   333MB
bref/x86-php80-function                 latest      3562db33bbad   359MB

bref/php-74                             latest      a508288169c9   331MB
bref/x86-php74-function                 latest      83031f11c8d2   357MB
```

### Checklist

- [x] Compile PHP 7.4
- [x] Compile PHP 8.0
- [x] Compile PHP 8.1
- [x] Function Layer PHP 7.4
- [x] Function Layer PHP 8.0
- [x] Function Layer PHP 8.1
- [x] FPM Layer PHP 7.4
- [x] FPM Layer PHP 8.0
- [x] FPM Layer PHP 8.1
- [ ] Console Layer
- [x] Cross Region Layer Publishing
- [x] Aggregate Layer vesion inside layers.json
- [x] Backward-compatible Image Tagging
- [x] Compile all base extensions
- [ ] Document docker-compose orchestration
- [x] Copy Event classes into the Layer to avoid Composer [Still needs to be tested!]
- [x] Decompose composer.json dependencies
- [ ] CI / CD Pipeline

#### CI / CD

- [x] Public AWS CodeBuild
- [x] `make everything` publishing all layers in parallel
- [x] Brefphp Bot PR
- [x] layers.x86.json
- [x] Update serverless-bref plugin to be architecture-aware
- [x] Run automation tests when pull request is opened.
- [x] Process to publish Docker Images on Docker Hub
- [ ] Tag Docker Images on Release (GitHub Actions)

#### Extensions

- [x] bcmath
- [x] ctype
- [x] curl
- [x] date
- [x] dom
- [x] exif
- [x] fileinfo
- [x] filter
- [x] ftp
- [x] gettext
- [x] hash
- [x] iconv
- [x] json
- [x] libxml
- [x] mbstring
- [x] mysqli
- [x] mysqlnd
- [x] opcache
- [x] openssl
- [x] pcntl
- [x] pcre
- [x] pdo
- [x] pdo_sqlite
- [x] pdo_mysql
- [x] phar
- [x] posix
- [x] readline
- [x] reflection
- [x] session
- [x] simplexml
- [x] sodium
- [x] soap
- [x] sockets
- [x] spl
- [x] sqlite3
- [x] tokenizer
- [x] xml
- [x] xmlreader
- [x] xmlwriter
- [x] xsl
- [x] zlib
- [x] intl
- [x] acpu
- [x] pdo_postgres

### Important Notes

Currently the process is blocked by https://github.com/docker/compose/issues/8804 for graviton support.

release.body:
This release introduces [PHP 8.2 stable](https://www.php.net/releases/8.2/en.php) 🎉 

You can start deploying with PHP 8.2 by replacing the PHP version in `serverless.yml`:

```diff
functions:
    api:
        handler: public/index.php
        layers:
-            - ${bref:layer.php-81}
+            - ${bref:layer.php-82}
```

If you don't use `serverless.yml`, check out [runtimes.bref.sh](runtimes.bref.sh) for a list of Lambda runtimes.

## All changes

* Support Europe/Spain region by @kevincerro in https://github.com/brefphp/bref/pull/1331
* PHP 8.2 stable released by @mykiwi in https://github.com/brefphp/bref/pull/1341

## New Contributors
* @kevincerro made their first contribution in https://github.com/brefphp/bref/pull/1331

**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/brefphp/bref/compare/1.7.12...1.7.13

issue.title: Bref 2.0
issue.body:
Hey @Nyholm!

As I work on Bref v2, I started testing the impact on the extra extensions. I think it _should_ be minimal.

So far I've been able to build redis, decimal, and ds by just replacing:

```diff
- FROM bref/build-php-$PHP_VERSION:1.7.4 AS ext
+ FROM --platform=linux/amd64 bref/build-php-$PHP_VERSION:latest AS ext
```

Note: I used `latest` so that it uses the local image I built from https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers Eventually you'll be able to use a real version like 2.0.0 or something similar.

The main change is to force using the x86 platform, else when building on M1 (for example) it tries to pick up the ARM images.

Bref v2 will also contain ARM images, I'm not sure if that implies also building extensions on ARM specifically, but I guess it might be the case. Not sure if this is something you want to tackle outright.

comment.body:
Right, the docker build images have actually changed a lot 😅 (https://github.com/brefphp/bref/issues/1299 for a longer summary).

For x86 images, we switch from compiling PHP to installed a compiled version from remi repo (Red Hat repo). For ARM images, we use Amazon Linux Extra packages. I've tried to have the build image break the least things possible for those extra extensions though. For example pecl is installed, along with all system "dev tools" (e.g. make, GCC, etc.). If you have specific extensions in mind that might be problematic, I can try to build those and test it btw.

That also means that some extensions could be actually installed (`yum install php-redis`) instead of compiled. That means much faster build times, but also implies changing existing scripts, so I wouldn't jump on that right away TBH.

issue.title: Signing published bref layers
issue.body:
**Expected:**

I can setup signing profile for improved security during app deployment and successfully deploy an application.
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/serverless-application-model/latest/developerguide/authoring-codesigning.html

**Actual:**

It fails or shows warning during stack deployment since bref layer isn't part of a trusted signing profile.

Lambda layers follow the same signed code package format as function code packages. When you add a layer to a function that has code signing enabled, Lambda checks that the layer is signed by an allowed signing profile. When you enable code signing for a function, all layers that are added to the function must also be signed by one of the allowed signing profiles.

https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/configuration-codesigning.html#config-codesigning-valid

**Possible solution:**

Sign layers during publishing and share aws sigining profile arn so it can be added  to the list of allowed signing profiles during deployment. 
https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/best-practices-and-advanced-patterns-for-lambda-code-signing/

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,13 +1,24 @@
+# syntax = docker/dockerfile:1.4
 ARG PHP_VERSION
-FROM bref/build-php-$PHP_VERSION:1.7.4 AS ext
+FROM bref/build-php-$PHP_VERSION:2 AS ext
+
+RUN <<eot bash -e
+yum install -y php-redis
+cat > /tmp/ext.ini <<INI
+extension=igbinary.so
+extension=msgpack.so
+extension=redis.so
+INI
+eot
 
-RUN pecl install --force redis
-RUN cp `php-config --extension-dir`/redis.so /tmp/redis.so
-RUN echo 'extension=/opt/bref-extra/redis.so' > /tmp/ext.ini
 
 # Build the final image with just the files we need
 FROM scratch
 
 # Copy things we installed to the final image
-COPY --from=ext /tmp/redis.so /opt/bref-extra/redis.so
+COPY --from=ext /usr/lib64/liblzf.so* /opt/lib/

issue.title: Consider public use of Bref\Runtime\LambdaRuntime for containers who does not inherit from bref/php-?? images
issue.body:
> **TL;TR** Consider public use of `Bref\Runtime\LambdaRuntime` for containers who does not inherit from `bref/php-??` images

After check all those announcements around the possibility of use custom container images for Lambda, I've feel those examples are unnecessary complicated.

All those examples assume you should inherit from AWS Lamda images (public.ecr.aws/lambda/*) when the only thing those images provide is the Lambda RIE used for local development/testing.

I have wrote an small example (https://github.com/Maks3w/php-lambda-example) showing how it could be possible base your custom containers in the official PHP images and only install Lambda RIE for development.

I think this approach is more simple than others where you have to deal with the installation of PHP or you have more PHP extensions than you really need.

In fact the example shows there is less room for `bref` for this kind of deployment. However there is still a need for manage the Lambda payloads received and the return of the results. These things are well implemented by *bref* in [`Bref\Runtime\LambdaRuntime`](https://github.com/brefphp/bref/blob/master/src/Runtime/LambdaRuntime.php)
but this class is tagged as `@internal` what it means no forward guaranteed compatibility.

It could be possible to open `Bref\Runtime\LambdaRuntime` as a public class?

issue.body:
> **TL;TR** Consider public use of `Bref\Runtime\LambdaRuntime` for containers who does not inherit from `bref/php-??` images

After check all those announcements around the possibility of use custom container images for Lambda, I've feel those examples are unnecessary complicated.

All those examples assume you should inherit from AWS Lamda images (public.ecr.aws/lambda/*) when the only thing those images provide is the Lambda RIE used for local development/testing.

I have wrote an small example (https://github.com/Maks3w/php-lambda-example) showing how it could be possible base your custom containers in the official PHP images and only install Lambda RIE for development.

I think this approach is more simple than others where you have to deal with the installation of PHP or you have more PHP extensions than you really need.

In fact the example shows there is less room for `bref` for this kind of deployment. However there is still a need for manage the Lambda payloads received and the return of the results. These things are well implemented by *bref* in [`Bref\Runtime\LambdaRuntime`](https://github.com/brefphp/bref/blob/master/src/Runtime/LambdaRuntime.php)

comment.body:
Hey everyone! I haven't forgotten about this :) 

In Bref 2, this will now be possible, and be actually simpler. The 3 different runtimes (fpm, function and console) now have each a public API, though slightly different from what was discussed here (i.e. that's what I mean by simpler).

### FPM

I actually moved the FPM runtime to a separate repository (https://github.com/brefphp/php-fpm-runtime), and its main entrypoint (bootstrap.php) is now a public API.

In short, [run `vendor/bref/php-fpm-runtime/src/bootstrap.php`](https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers/blob/5e248826993c467d539ff55498ed9291b16d7f66/layers/fpm/bootstrap.sh#L12).

### Function

Require `bref/bref` and [run `Bref\FunctionRuntime\Main::run()`](https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers/blob/5e248826993c467d539ff55498ed9291b16d7f66/layers/function/bootstrap.php#L17).

### Function

Require `bref/bref` and [run `Bref\ConsoleRuntime\Main::run()`](https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers/blob/5e248826993c467d539ff55498ed9291b16d7f66/layers/console/bref/bootstrap.php#L5).

🤦

To answer your question, yes we copy a lot of libs: https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers/blob/main/php-80/cpu-x86.Dockerfile#L41 (FYI `/bref/lib` becomes `/opt/lib` in these images)

But you made me realize that we copy them to `/opt/lib` (in Bref 2 I mean). All is good, sorry ^^

issue.title: Bref 2.0
issue.body:
Hey @Nyholm!

As I work on Bref v2, I started testing the impact on the extra extensions. I think it _should_ be minimal.

So far I've been able to build redis, decimal, and ds by just replacing:

```diff
- FROM bref/build-php-$PHP_VERSION:1.7.4 AS ext
+ FROM --platform=linux/amd64 bref/build-php-$PHP_VERSION:latest AS ext
```

Note: I used `latest` so that it uses the local image I built from https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers Eventually you'll be able to use a real version like 2.0.0 or something similar.

The main change is to force using the x86 platform, else when building on M1 (for example) it tries to pick up the ARM images.

Bref v2 will also contain ARM images, I'm not sure if that implies also building extensions on ARM specifically, but I guess it might be the case. Not sure if this is something you want to tackle outright.

comment.body:
> @mnapoli as we use Makefiles, looks like a better option to set DOCKER_DEFAULT_PLATFORM env var for example than putting a --platform=linux/amd64 option into the FROM instruction of Dockerfiles.

Makes sense to me, not sure if you have an opinion on this @Nyholm.

TBH I don't have a strong opinion on this, I don't know much better than you on this.

I created the branch: https://github.com/brefphp/extra-php-extensions/tree/v2

Do you think I should also move the "lib" directory in the base Bref images? I'm confused why I haven't faced this problem there 🤔

issue.title: Bref 2.0: rewritten runtimes
issue.body:
This issue is about one big change in Bref 2.0: new (rewritten) runtimes. This issue only covers this change.

## Background

@deleugpn worked a lot on the runtimes/layers, and started working on #1078 to completely refactor how they are built.

The PR stalled earlier this year, I am picking it back up and finishing the changes for Bref 2.0. Feel free to read the PR, but it doesn't reflect 100% what we have now.

## Goals

1. Easier to maintain and contribute
2. #1043 (thanks to the above)
3. Improve Bref compatibility with Terraform, AWS CDK, Pulumi…
4. Allow newcomers to test Bref in the AWS console without installing it

Not a direct goal, but a pleasant side-effect: makes it easier for advanced users to create their own runtime/customize the existing runtimes.

## User impact

Everything will continue to work like in v1 (there will just be more "possibilities"), no code changes should be necessary.

It will be a new major version because we are changing the way PHP is compiled, and it might impact extra layers or extensions. The goal is to be safe.

## Details

### 1. Easier to maintain and contribute

How:

- Install PHP from a distribution instead of compiling it.
- The point above also led to much simpler and faster scripts.
- Added automated tests for the runtimes.
- Added commands so contributors can easily build, test, and upload layers.
- Refactorings/code reorganization.

The work in progress is in this repository: https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers 
This repository contains all the git history of Bref (`runtime/` directory) and #1043 on top of it. However newer commits are not included (too hard to rebase everything).

Trade-offs:

- We install PHP from [Remi Collet's repository](https://blog.remirepo.net/en): this is a trusted, reliable and **up-to-date** repository from a core PHP contributor (more [details here](https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers#installing-php-from-a-distribution)), but we become dependent on a 3rd party.
- v2 layers will probably be published to a new AWS account, to avoid any possible error for Bref v1 users that want to stay on this version.


### 2. Add Graviton/ARM support (#1043)

How:

- Thanks to the simplification, adding Graviton support becomes easier.
- Remi doesn't distribute arm builds, we install PHP from `amazon-linux-extras`.

Trade-offs:

- `amazon-linux-extras` is 5 months behind PHP's schedule and doesn't support PHP 8.1 yet.

### 3. Improve Bref compatibility with Terraform, AWS CDK, Pulumi…

How:

- Break the current coupling between layers and Bref's code: that will make upgrading layers decoupled from the Bref version.
- Make exposing Bref layers (layers.json) in more format (e.g. NPM package) easier to do, because it's decoupled to Bref's codebase.

Want to see what this looks like? Here's an example with the "function" runtime:

- [`bootstrap.sh`](https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers/blob/9d96433885a32422a04af8773282cbe216bd1fb8/layers/function/bootstrap.sh) is the Lambda entrypoint, it runs `bootstrap.php`
- [`bootstrap.php`](https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers/blob/9d96433885a32422a04af8773282cbe216bd1fb8/layers/function/bootstrap.php) has no dependencies, it runs Bref's function runtime from the user's vendor directory
- Bref's function runtime should be installed by Bref users (will be required by bref/bref, so it's transparent), here is the repo: https://github.com/brefphp/php-runtime

With the solution described above, the layer is 100% decoupled from Bref's codebase. It is possible to upgrade layers and Bref separately.

Trade-offs:

- Possibly a more complex codebase (e.g. multi-repo) for maintainers.
- Requires more automation/orchestration of Bref releases.
- So far I had to remove the feature "[separate vendor directory](https://bref.sh/docs/environment/php.html#separate-vendor-folder)" because it made things much harder. I don't think this feature is used a lot, and it is poorly maintained (community-contributed), source of a lot of frustration. I'm fine dropping it.

### 4. Allow newcomers to test Bref in the AWS console without installing it

How:

- FPM layers become self-contained and do not require the Bref codebase.

Indeed, the user codebase runs in FPM and is not coupled to the Bref API (when using the FPM layer). That means we can create an FPM layer that contains all the code it needs to run. Users can create an empty Lambda function with a single `index.php` and things will work.

Prototype of externalizing the FPM runtime: https://github.com/brefphp/php-fpm-runtime (the FPM layer contains this code, Bref users do not have to install it anymore).

Trade-offs:

- Move from a monolithic codebase (one version, one repo) to multiple repositories.

----

Feedback is welcome.

I am currently building layers and will post layers ARNs soon if you want to test things out and participate.

comment.body:
Getting close to finishing!

Today I worked on the dev images and I have found an interesting approach that could simplify local development. Curious to get your feedback: https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers/pull/38

pull_request.title: Bref 2 dev images
pull_request.body: While porting Bref 1 "dev" images to Bref 2, I was looking at how to improve the DX for users. I think I managed to find an interesting result that combines all use cases into a single "dev" image that works out of the box, with xdebug and blackfire. I recorded a video to show it in more details if you are interested: https://youtu.be/0PnreyR8c58 If you don't have time for the video, here's a quick example: ### Bref v1 ```yaml services: web: image: bref/fpm-dev-gateway ports: - '8000:80' volumes: - .:/var/task depends_on: - php environment: HANDLER: public/index.php DOCUMENT_ROOT: public app: image: bref/php-80-fpm-dev volumes: - .:/var/task console: image: bref/php-80 volumes: - .:/var/task entrypoint: php ``` ### Bref v2 ```yaml services: app: image: bref/php-80-fpm-dev ports: [ '8000:8000' ] volumes: - .:/var/task environment: HANDLER: public/index.php DOCUMENT_ROOT: public ```

commits.message: Fix #1291 Remove `@internal` tags on classes that now become public API

Merge pull request #1345 from brefphp/remove-internal-tags

Fix https://github.com/brefphp/bref/issues/1291

pull_request.title: Remove `@internal` tags on classes that now become public API
pull_request.body:
Fix #1291

In previous open-source projects, I never thought twice about making classes `@internal`. That meant that any code I wrote for internal purposes was instantly part of the public API of the package.

Over the years, this caused me a lot of issues because I had to keep backward compatibility for that code. Even though (very likely) nobody was actually using it. This made maintenance and refactorings much harder.

When I worked on Bref, I added the `@internal` tag by default on all code I wrote that wasn't meant to be used by end users.

Now that we have a few years of experience, I can see that some of this code is very stable (no need to refactor it), and could actually be useful outside of Bref.

So let's open it up! This PR removes a lot of `@internal` tags and makes this internal code part of the public API. It will be maintained and free of breaking changes in minor versions.

Hey @Nyholm!

As I work on Bref v2, I started testing the impact on the extra extensions. I think it _should_ be minimal.

So far I've been able to build redis, decimal, and ds by just replacing:

```diff
- FROM bref/build-php-$PHP_VERSION:1.7.4 AS ext
+ FROM --platform=linux/amd64 bref/build-php-$PHP_VERSION:latest AS ext
```

Note: I used `latest` so that it uses the local image I built from https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers Eventually you'll be able to use a real version like 2.0.0 or something similar.

The main change is to force using the x86 platform, else when building on M1 (for example) it tries to pick up the ARM images.

Bref v2 will also contain ARM images, I'm not sure if that implies also building extensions on ARM specifically, but I guess it might be the case. Not sure if this is something you want to tackle outright.

pull_request.title: [Proposal] Runtime changes
pull_request.body:
This pull request is an ongoing work with an attempt to drastically change the Runtime system.

### Why?

It's an attempt to make things easier to change. Although it was triggered by AWS releasing Graviton support on Lambda, this pull request isn't entirely about supporting Graviton, but in fact making it easier and more accessible to build, test and reproduce the layers provided by Bref.

### What are the changes?

- The expected result is ann easier to reproduce system by leveraging primarily Docker and Docker Compose.
- Instead of compiling PHP, we delegate that work to reliable sources like Remi Collect ([recommendation](https://twitter.com/peter_kokot/status/1444642270976921602))
- Simplify the process to become more accessible for us PHP Developers
- ~Steal~ Take inspiration from the folks at Vercel ([Source](https://github.com/juicyfx/libphp/blob/master/libs/amazon-linux-2-v80/Makefile#L53))

#### What does it mean for new PHP releases?

Although compiling PHP means we're in control of compiling point releases as soon as they come, remi-collect has a great track record of releasing new version on the same day (or even the day before) a new version is announced on the PHP internal list. The downside is that Remi doesn't provide aarch64 support, which means we would need to rely on `amazon-linux-extras` for Graviton support. Currently Amazon only provides PHP 8.0.8 (about 4 months behind). My take is that it's better to provide delayed aarch64 than not provide at all or provide it using emulators or in a hard-to-maintain process. Given that Apple is pushing arm64 with the new M1 laptops and AWS is pushing it via Graviton support, it's a matter of time until there's better release cycle around arm64.

### How does it work?

The project structure is divided into `common`, `phpxx`, `tests` and the root folder.

The `common` folder contains files for the fpm layer, function layer and the scripts for publishing the layers. The FPM and Function layers are built by using `composer install` and generating a `vendor` folder that will be embedded and available inside the Lambda Layer.

The `php74`, `php80` and `php81` folders are suppose to be incredibly identical and easy to test and replicate. Each PHP Folder has it's own Makefile so that contributors can `make function` and publish their own layer in their own account. This allows for easy testing for layers modifications.

The `tests` folder contains assertions that will be executed inside the container of each layer so that we can "prove" that the system works.

Finally, the root folder contains a Makefile and a docker-compose file that allows for parallelization of building all layers / php versions and publishing them on all regions.

Special thanks to [Aran Reeks](https://twitter.com/AranReeks/status/1445106462443937792?t=L4IeLGy1zpN855BfJe4LeQ&s=19) for teaching me about `ldd` to show linked libraries for the php binary and its extensions.

### What is the `/opt/bref-internal-src` folder?

This is an attempt to make PHP on Lambda easier to onboard and test. It allows to replicate the experience of other Runtime. You go to the AWS Console, create a new Function, attach Bref's layer to it, write a `hello.php` file and run it. No need for `composer` or `serverless`. Just plain old PHP. It greatly improves the User Experience when testing things out.

### How can I test this myself?

The biggest motivation for this pull request is to make it easier for anyone/everyone build their own layer so that you can test things out yourself. Making it more reproducible / accessible will help contributors changing the layer to test things. Here are the steps:

```
git clone git@github.com:brefphp/bref.git
cd bref
git checkout runtime
cd runtime
cd php81

# Modify the Makefile with your AWS credentials

# Run the project tests
make test 

# Publish your own `function` layer
make function

# Publish your own `fpm` layer
make fpm
```

These steps will publish a new layer into your own AWS Account so that you can test them.

### Comparison

```
bref/php-81                             latest      127c04144153   333MB
bref/x86-php81-function                 latest      c46d3edc8846   361MB

bref/php-80                             latest      1300e903c67e   333MB
bref/x86-php80-function                 latest      3562db33bbad   359MB

bref/php-74                             latest      a508288169c9   331MB
bref/x86-php74-function                 latest      83031f11c8d2   357MB
```

### Checklist

- [x] Compile PHP 7.4
- [x] Compile PHP 8.0
- [x] Compile PHP 8.1
- [x] Function Layer PHP 7.4
- [x] Function Layer PHP 8.0
- [x] Function Layer PHP 8.1
- [x] FPM Layer PHP 7.4
- [x] FPM Layer PHP 8.0
- [x] FPM Layer PHP 8.1
- [ ] Console Layer
- [x] Cross Region Layer Publishing
- [x] Aggregate Layer vesion inside layers.json
- [x] Backward-compatible Image Tagging
- [x] Compile all base extensions
- [ ] Document docker-compose orchestration
- [x] Copy Event classes into the Layer to avoid Composer [Still needs to be tested!]
- [x] Decompose composer.json dependencies
- [ ] CI / CD Pipeline

#### CI / CD

- [x] Public AWS CodeBuild
- [x] `make everything` publishing all layers in parallel
- [x] Brefphp Bot PR
- [x] layers.x86.json
- [x] Update serverless-bref plugin to be architecture-aware
- [x] Run automation tests when pull request is opened.
- [x] Process to publish Docker Images on Docker Hub
- [ ] Tag Docker Images on Release (GitHub Actions)

#### Extensions

- [x] bcmath
- [x] ctype
- [x] curl
- [x] date
- [x] dom
- [x] exif
- [x] fileinfo
- [x] filter
- [x] ftp
- [x] gettext
- [x] hash
- [x] iconv
- [x] json
- [x] libxml
- [x] mbstring
- [x] mysqli
- [x] mysqlnd
- [x] opcache
- [x] openssl
- [x] pcntl
- [x] pcre
- [x] pdo
- [x] pdo_sqlite
- [x] pdo_mysql
- [x] phar
- [x] posix
- [x] readline
- [x] reflection
- [x] session
- [x] simplexml
- [x] sodium
- [x] soap
- [x] sockets
- [x] spl
- [x] sqlite3
- [x] tokenizer
- [x] xml
- [x] xmlreader
- [x] xmlwriter
- [x] xsl
- [x] zlib
- [x] intl
- [x] acpu
- [x] pdo_postgres

### Important Notes

Currently the process is blocked by https://github.com/docker/compose/issues/8804 for graviton support.

release.body:
This release introduces [PHP 8.2 stable](https://www.php.net/releases/8.2/en.php) 🎉 

You can start deploying with PHP 8.2 by replacing the PHP version in `serverless.yml`:

```diff
functions:
    api:
        handler: public/index.php
        layers:
-            - ${bref:layer.php-81}
+            - ${bref:layer.php-82}
```

If you don't use `serverless.yml`, check out [runtimes.bref.sh](runtimes.bref.sh) for a list of Lambda runtimes.

## All changes

* Support Europe/Spain region by @kevincerro in https://github.com/brefphp/bref/pull/1331
* PHP 8.2 stable released by @mykiwi in https://github.com/brefphp/bref/pull/1341

## New Contributors

**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/brefphp/bref/compare/1.7.12...1.7.13

issue.title: Bref 2.0
issue.body:
Hey @Nyholm!

As I work on Bref v2, I started testing the impact on the extra extensions. I think it _should_ be minimal.

So far I've been able to build redis, decimal, and ds by just replacing:

```diff
- FROM bref/build-php-$PHP_VERSION:1.7.4 AS ext
+ FROM --platform=linux/amd64 bref/build-php-$PHP_VERSION:latest AS ext
```

Note: I used `latest` so that it uses the local image I built from https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers Eventually you'll be able to use a real version like 2.0.0 or something similar.

The main change is to force using the x86 platform, else when building on M1 (for example) it tries to pick up the ARM images.

Bref v2 will also contain ARM images, I'm not sure if that implies also building extensions on ARM specifically, but I guess it might be the case. Not sure if this is something you want to tackle outright.

comment.body:
Right, the docker build images have actually changed a lot 😅 (https://github.com/brefphp/bref/issues/1299 for a longer summary).

For x86 images, we switch from compiling PHP to installed a compiled version from remi repo (Red Hat repo). For ARM images, we use Amazon Linux Extra packages. I've tried to have the build image break the least things possible for those extra extensions though. For example pecl is installed, along with all system "dev tools" (e.g. make, GCC, etc.). If you have specific extensions in mind that might be problematic, I can try to build those and test it btw.

That also means that some extensions could be actually installed (`yum install php-redis`) instead of compiled. That means much faster build times, but also implies changing existing scripts, so I wouldn't jump on that right away TBH.

issue.title: Signing published bref layers
issue.body:
**Expected:**

I can setup signing profile for improved security during app deployment and successfully deploy an application.
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/serverless-application-model/latest/developerguide/authoring-codesigning.html

**Actual:**

It fails or shows warning during stack deployment since bref layer isn't part of a trusted signing profile.

Lambda layers follow the same signed code package format as function code packages. When you add a layer to a function that has code signing enabled, Lambda checks that the layer is signed by an allowed signing profile. When you enable code signing for a function, all layers that are added to the function must also be signed by one of the allowed signing profiles.

https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/configuration-codesigning.html#config-codesigning-valid

**Possible solution:**

Sign layers during publishing and share aws sigining profile arn so it can be added  to the list of allowed signing profiles during deployment. 
https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/best-practices-and-advanced-patterns-for-lambda-code-signing/

+
+RUN <<eot bash -e
+yum install -y php-redis
+cat > /tmp/ext.ini <<INI
+extension=igbinary.so
+extension=msgpack.so
+extension=redis.so
+INI
+eot
 
-RUN pecl install --force redis
-RUN cp `php-config --extension-dir`/redis.so /tmp/redis.so
-RUN echo 'extension=/opt/bref-extra/redis.so' > /tmp/ext.ini
 
 # Build the final image with just the files we need
 FROM scratch
 
 # Copy things we installed to the final image
-COPY --from=ext /tmp/redis.so /opt/bref-extra/redis.so
+COPY --from=ext /usr/lib64/liblzf.so* /opt/lib/

issue.title: Consider public use of Bref\Runtime\LambdaRuntime for containers who does not inherit from bref/php-?? images
issue.body:
> **TL;TR** Consider public use of `Bref\Runtime\LambdaRuntime` for containers who does not inherit from `bref/php-??` images

After check all those announcements around the possibility of use custom container images for Lambda, I've feel those examples are unnecessary complicated.

All those examples assume you should inherit from AWS Lamda images (public.ecr.aws/lambda/*) when the only thing those images provide is the Lambda RIE used for local development/testing.

I have wrote an small example (https://github.com/Maks3w/php-lambda-example) showing how it could be possible base your custom containers in the official PHP images and only install Lambda RIE for development.

I think this approach is more simple than others where you have to deal with the installation of PHP or you have more PHP extensions than you really need.

In fact the example shows there is less room for `bref` for this kind of deployment. However there is still a need for manage the Lambda payloads received and the return of the results. These things are well implemented by *bref* in [`Bref\Runtime\LambdaRuntime`](https://github.com/brefphp/bref/blob/master/src/Runtime/LambdaRuntime.php)
but this class is tagged as `@internal` what it means no forward guaranteed compatibility.

It could be possible to open `Bref\Runtime\LambdaRuntime` as a public class?

issue.title: Consider public use of Bref\Runtime\LambdaRuntime for containers who does not inherit from bref/php-?? images
issue.body:

All those examples assume you should inherit from AWS Lamda images (public.ecr.aws/lambda/*) when the only thing those images provide is the Lambda RIE used for local development/testing.

In fact the example shows there is less room for `bref` for this kind of deployment. However there is still a need for manage the Lambda payloads received and the return of the results. These things are well implemented by *bref* in [`Bref\Runtime\LambdaRuntime`](https://github.com/brefphp/bref/blob/master/src/Runtime/LambdaRuntime.php)
but this class is tagged as `@internal` what it means no forward guaranteed compatibility.

It could be possible to open `Bref\Runtime\LambdaRuntime` as a public class?

comment.body:
Hey everyone! I haven't forgotten about this :) 

In Bref 2, this will now be possible, and be actually simpler. The 3 different runtimes (fpm, function and console) now have each a public API, though slightly different from what was discussed here (i.e. that's what I mean by simpler).

### FPM

I actually moved the FPM runtime to a separate repository (https://github.com/brefphp/php-fpm-runtime), and its main entrypoint (bootstrap.php) is now a public API.

In short, [run `vendor/bref/php-fpm-runtime/src/bootstrap.php`](https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers/blob/5e248826993c467d539ff55498ed9291b16d7f66/layers/fpm/bootstrap.sh#L12).

### Function

Require `bref/bref` and [run `Bref\FunctionRuntime\Main::run()`](https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers/blob/5e248826993c467d539ff55498ed9291b16d7f66/layers/function/bootstrap.php#L17).

### Function

Require `bref/bref` and [run `Bref\ConsoleRuntime\Main::run()`](https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers/blob/5e248826993c467d539ff55498ed9291b16d7f66/layers/console/bref/bootstrap.php#L5).

🤦

To answer your question, yes we copy a lot of libs: https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers/blob/main/php-80/cpu-x86.Dockerfile#L41 (FYI `/bref/lib` becomes `/opt/lib` in these images)

But you made me realize that we copy them to `/opt/lib` (in Bref 2 I mean). All is good, sorry ^^

issue.title: Bref 2.0
issue.body:
Hey @Nyholm!

As I work on Bref v2, I started testing the impact on the extra extensions. I think it _should_ be minimal.

So far I've been able to build redis, decimal, and ds by just replacing:

```diff
- FROM bref/build-php-$PHP_VERSION:1.7.4 AS ext
+ FROM --platform=linux/amd64 bref/build-php-$PHP_VERSION:latest AS ext
```

Note: I used `latest` so that it uses the local image I built from https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers Eventually you'll be able to use a real version like 2.0.0 or something similar.

The main change is to force using the x86 platform, else when building on M1 (for example) it tries to pick up the ARM images.

Bref v2 will also contain ARM images, I'm not sure if that implies also building extensions on ARM specifically, but I guess it might be the case. Not sure if this is something you want to tackle outright.

comment.body:

TBH I don't have a strong opinion on this, I don't know much better than you on this.

I created the branch: https://github.com/brefphp/extra-php-extensions/tree/v2

Do you think I should also move the "lib" directory in the base Bref images? I'm confused why I haven't faced this problem there 🤔

issue.title: Bref 2.0: rewritten runtimes
issue.body:
This issue is about one big change in Bref 2.0: new (rewritten) runtimes. This issue only covers this change.

## Background

@deleugpn worked a lot on the runtimes/layers, and started working on #1078 to completely refactor how they are built.

The PR stalled earlier this year, I am picking it back up and finishing the changes for Bref 2.0. Feel free to read the PR, but it doesn't reflect 100% what we have now.

## Goals

1. Easier to maintain and contribute
2. #1043 (thanks to the above)
3. Improve Bref compatibility with Terraform, AWS CDK, Pulumi…
4. Allow newcomers to test Bref in the AWS console without installing it

Not a direct goal, but a pleasant side-effect: makes it easier for advanced users to create their own runtime/customize the existing runtimes.

## User impact

Everything will continue to work like in v1 (there will just be more "possibilities"), no code changes should be necessary.

It will be a new major version because we are changing the way PHP is compiled, and it might impact extra layers or extensions. The goal is to be safe.

## Details

### 1. Easier to maintain and contribute

How:

- Install PHP from a distribution instead of compiling it.
- The point above also led to much simpler and faster scripts.
- Added automated tests for the runtimes.
- Added commands so contributors can easily build, test, and upload layers.
- Refactorings/code reorganization.

The work in progress is in this repository: https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers 
This repository contains all the git history of Bref (`runtime/` directory) and #1043 on top of it. However newer commits are not included (too hard to rebase everything).

Trade-offs:

- We install PHP from [Remi Collet's repository](https://blog.remirepo.net/en): this is a trusted, reliable and **up-to-date** repository from a core PHP contributor (more [details here](https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers#installing-php-from-a-distribution)), but we become dependent on a 3rd party.
- v2 layers will probably be published to a new AWS account, to avoid any possible error for Bref v1 users that want to stay on this version.


### 2. Add Graviton/ARM support (#1043)

How:

- Thanks to the simplification, adding Graviton support becomes easier.
- Remi doesn't distribute arm builds, we install PHP from `amazon-linux-extras`.

Trade-offs:

- `amazon-linux-extras` is 5 months behind PHP's schedule and doesn't support PHP 8.1 yet.

### 3. Improve Bref compatibility with Terraform, AWS CDK, Pulumi…

How:

- Break the current coupling between layers and Bref's code: that will make upgrading layers decoupled from the Bref version.
- Make exposing Bref layers (layers.json) in more format (e.g. NPM package) easier to do, because it's decoupled to Bref's codebase.

Want to see what this looks like? Here's an example with the "function" runtime:

- [`bootstrap.sh`](https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers/blob/9d96433885a32422a04af8773282cbe216bd1fb8/layers/function/bootstrap.sh) is the Lambda entrypoint, it runs `bootstrap.php`
- [`bootstrap.php`](https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers/blob/9d96433885a32422a04af8773282cbe216bd1fb8/layers/function/bootstrap.php) has no dependencies, it runs Bref's function runtime from the user's vendor directory
- Bref's function runtime should be installed by Bref users (will be required by bref/bref, so it's transparent), here is the repo: https://github.com/brefphp/php-runtime

With the solution described above, the layer is 100% decoupled from Bref's codebase. It is possible to upgrade layers and Bref separately.

Trade-offs:

- Possibly a more complex codebase (e.g. multi-repo) for maintainers.
- Requires more automation/orchestration of Bref releases.
- So far I had to remove the feature "[separate vendor directory](https://bref.sh/docs/environment/php.html#separate-vendor-folder)" because it made things much harder. I don't think this feature is used a lot, and it is poorly maintained (community-contributed), source of a lot of frustration. I'm fine dropping it.

### 4. Allow newcomers to test Bref in the AWS console without installing it

How:

- FPM layers become self-contained and do not require the Bref codebase.

Indeed, the user codebase runs in FPM and is not coupled to the Bref API (when using the FPM layer). That means we can create an FPM layer that contains all the code it needs to run. Users can create an empty Lambda function with a single `index.php` and things will work.

Prototype of externalizing the FPM runtime: https://github.com/brefphp/php-fpm-runtime (the FPM layer contains this code, Bref users do not have to install it anymore).

Trade-offs:

- Move from a monolithic codebase (one version, one repo) to multiple repositories.

----

Feedback is welcome.

I am currently building layers and will post layers ARNs soon if you want to test things out and participate.

pull_request.title: Bref 2 dev images
pull_request.body: While porting Bref 1 "dev" images to Bref 2, I was looking at how to improve the DX for users. I think I managed to find an interesting result that combines all use cases into a single "dev" image that works out of the box, with xdebug and blackfire. I recorded a video to show it in more details if you are interested: https://youtu.be/0PnreyR8c58 If you don't have time for the video, here's a quick example: ### Bref v1 ```yaml services: web: image: bref/fpm-dev-gateway ports: - '8000:80' volumes: - .:/var/task depends_on: - php environment: HANDLER: public/index.php DOCUMENT_ROOT: public app: image: bref/php-80-fpm-dev volumes: - .:/var/task console: image: bref/php-80 volumes: - .:/var/task entrypoint: php ``` ### Bref v2 ```yaml services: app: image: bref/php-80-fpm-dev ports: [ '8000:8000' ] volumes: - .:/var/task environment: HANDLER: public/index.php DOCUMENT_ROOT: public ```

Merge pull request #1345 from brefphp/remove-internal-tags

Fix https://github.com/brefphp/bref/issues/1291

pull_request.title: Remove `@internal` tags on classes that now become public API
pull_request.body:
Fix #1291

In previous open-source projects, I never thought twice about making classes `@internal`. That meant that any code I wrote for internal purposes was instantly part of the public API of the package.

Over the years, this caused me a lot of issues because I had to keep backward compatibility for that code. Even though (very likely) nobody was actually using it. This made maintenance and refactorings much harder.

When I worked on Bref, I added the `@internal` tag by default on all code I wrote that wasn't meant to be used by end users.

Now that we have a few years of experience, I can see that some of this code is very stable (no need to refactor it), and could actually be useful outside of Bref.

So let's open it up! This PR removes a lot of `@internal` tags and makes this internal code part of the public API. It will be maintained and free of breaking changes in minor versions.

pull_request.title: [Proposal] Runtime changes
pull_request.body:
This pull request is an ongoing work with an attempt to drastically change the Runtime system.

### Why?

It's an attempt to make things easier to change. Although it was triggered by AWS releasing Graviton support on Lambda, this pull request isn't entirely about supporting Graviton, but in fact making it easier and more accessible to build, test and reproduce the layers provided by Bref.

### What are the changes?

- The expected result is ann easier to reproduce system by leveraging primarily Docker and Docker Compose.
- Instead of compiling PHP, we delegate that work to reliable sources like Remi Collect ([recommendation](https://twitter.com/peter_kokot/status/1444642270976921602))
- Simplify the process to become more accessible for us PHP Developers
- ~Steal~ Take inspiration from the folks at Vercel ([Source](https://github.com/juicyfx/libphp/blob/master/libs/amazon-linux-2-v80/Makefile#L53))

#### What does it mean for new PHP releases?

Although compiling PHP means we're in control of compiling point releases as soon as they come, remi-collect has a great track record of releasing new version on the same day (or even the day before) a new version is announced on the PHP internal list. The downside is that Remi doesn't provide aarch64 support, which means we would need to rely on `amazon-linux-extras` for Graviton support. Currently Amazon only provides PHP 8.0.8 (about 4 months behind). My take is that it's better to provide delayed aarch64 than not provide at all or provide it using emulators or in a hard-to-maintain process. Given that Apple is pushing arm64 with the new M1 laptops and AWS is pushing it via Graviton support, it's a matter of time until there's better release cycle around arm64.

### How does it work?

The project structure is divided into `common`, `phpxx`, `tests` and the root folder.

The `common` folder contains files for the fpm layer, function layer and the scripts for publishing the layers. The FPM and Function layers are built by using `composer install` and generating a `vendor` folder that will be embedded and available inside the Lambda Layer.

The `php74`, `php80` and `php81` folders are suppose to be incredibly identical and easy to test and replicate. Each PHP Folder has it's own Makefile so that contributors can `make function` and publish their own layer in their own account. This allows for easy testing for layers modifications.

The `tests` folder contains assertions that will be executed inside the container of each layer so that we can "prove" that the system works.

Finally, the root folder contains a Makefile and a docker-compose file that allows for parallelization of building all layers / php versions and publishing them on all regions.

Special thanks to [Aran Reeks](https://twitter.com/AranReeks/status/1445106462443937792?t=L4IeLGy1zpN855BfJe4LeQ&s=19) for teaching me about `ldd` to show linked libraries for the php binary and its extensions.

### What is the `/opt/bref-internal-src` folder?

This is an attempt to make PHP on Lambda easier to onboard and test. It allows to replicate the experience of other Runtime. You go to the AWS Console, create a new Function, attach Bref's layer to it, write a `hello.php` file and run it. No need for `composer` or `serverless`. Just plain old PHP. It greatly improves the User Experience when testing things out.

### How can I test this myself?

The biggest motivation for this pull request is to make it easier for anyone/everyone build their own layer so that you can test things out yourself. Making it more reproducible / accessible will help contributors changing the layer to test things. Here are the steps:

```
git clone git@github.com:brefphp/bref.git
cd bref
git checkout runtime
cd runtime
cd php81

# Modify the Makefile with your AWS credentials

# Run the project tests
make test 

# Publish your own `function` layer
make function

# Publish your own `fpm` layer
make fpm
```

These steps will publish a new layer into your own AWS Account so that you can test them.

### Comparison

```
bref/php-81                             latest      127c04144153   333MB
bref/x86-php81-function                 latest      c46d3edc8846   361MB

bref/php-80                             latest      1300e903c67e   333MB

issue.title: [Proposal] Runtime changes
issue.body:
This pull request is an ongoing work with an attempt to drastically change the Runtime system.

### Why?

It's an attempt to make things easier to change. Although it was triggered by AWS releasing Graviton support on Lambda, this pull request isn't entirely about supporting Graviton, but in fact making it easier and more accessible to build, test and reproduce the layers provided by Bref.

### What are the changes?

- The expected result is ann easier to reproduce system by leveraging primarily Docker and Docker Compose.
- Instead of compiling PHP, we delegate that work to reliable sources like Remi Collect ([recommendation](https://twitter.com/peter_kokot/status/1444642270976921602))
- Simplify the process to become more accessible for us PHP Developers
- ~Steal~ Take inspiration from the folks at Vercel ([Source](https://github.com/juicyfx/libphp/blob/master/libs/amazon-linux-2-v80/Makefile#L53))

#### What does it mean for new PHP releases?

Although compiling PHP means we're in control of compiling point releases as soon as they come, remi-collect has a great track record of releasing new version on the same day (or even the day before) a new version is announced on the PHP internal list. The downside is that Remi doesn't provide aarch64 support, which means we would need to rely on `amazon-linux-extras` for Graviton support. Currently Amazon only provides PHP 8.0.8 (about 4 months behind). My take is that it's better to provide delayed aarch64 than not provide at all or provide it using emulators or in a hard-to-maintain process. release.body:
This release introduces [PHP 8.2 stable](https://www.php.net/releases/8.2/en.php) 🎉 

You can start deploying with PHP 8.2 by replacing the PHP version in `serverless.yml`:

```diff
functions:
    api:
        handler: public/index.php
        layers:
-            - ${bref:layer.php-81}
+            - ${bref:layer.php-82}
```

If you don't use `serverless.yml`, check out [runtimes.bref.sh](runtimes.bref.sh) for a list of Lambda runtimes.

## All changes

* Support Europe/Spain region by @kevincerro in https://github.com/brefphp/bref/pull/1331
* PHP 8.2 stable released by @mykiwi in https://github.com/brefphp/bref/pull/1341

## New Contributors
* @kevincerro made their first contribution in https://github.com/brefphp/bref/pull/1331

**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/brefphp/bref/compare/1.7.12...1.7.13

issue.title: Bref 2.0
issue.body:
Hey @Nyholm!

As I work on Bref v2, I started testing the impact on the extra extensions. I think it _should_ be minimal.

So far I've been able to build redis, decimal, and ds by just replacing:

```diff
- FROM bref/build-php-$PHP_VERSION:1.7.4 AS ext
+ FROM --platform=linux/amd64 bref/build-php-$PHP_VERSION:latest AS ext
```

Note: I used `latest` so that it uses the local image I built from https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers Eventually you'll be able to use a real version like 2.0.0 or something similar.

The main change is to force using the x86 platform, else when building on M1 (for example) it tries to pick up the ARM images.

Bref v2 will also contain ARM images, I'm not sure if that implies also building extensions on ARM specifically, but I guess it might be the case. Not sure if this is something you want to tackle outright.

comment.body:
Right, the docker build images have actually changed a lot 😅 (https://github.com/brefphp/bref/issues/1299 for a longer summary).

For x86 images, we switch from compiling PHP to installed a compiled version from remi repo (Red Hat repo). For ARM images, we use Amazon Linux Extra packages. I've tried to have the build image break the least things possible for those extra extensions though. For example pecl is installed, along with all system "dev tools" (e.g. make, GCC, etc.). If you have specific extensions in mind that might be problematic, I can try to build those and test it btw.

That also means that some extensions could be actually installed (`yum install php-redis`) instead of compiled. That means much faster build times, but also implies changing existing scripts, so I wouldn't jump on that right away TBH.

issue.title: Bref 2.0
issue.body:
Hey @Nyholm!

As I work on Bref v2, I started testing the impact on the extra extensions. I think it _should_ be minimal.

So far I've been able to build redis, decimal, and ds by just replacing:

```diff
- FROM bref/build-php-$PHP_VERSION:1.7.4 AS ext
+ FROM --platform=linux/amd64 bref/build-php-$PHP_VERSION:latest AS ext
```

Note: I used `latest` so that it uses the local image I built from https://github.com/brefphp/aws-lambda-layers Eventually you'll be able to use a real version like 2.0.0 or something similar.

The main change is to force using the x86 platform, else when building on M1 (for example) it tries to pick up the ARM images.

Bref v2 will also contain ARM images, I'm not sure if that implies also building extensions on ARM specifically, but I guess it might be the case. Not sure if this is something you want to tackle outright.

issue.title: Signing published bref layers
issue.body:
**Expected:**

I can setup signing profile for improved security during app deployment and successfully deploy an application.
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/serverless-application-model/latest/developerguide/authoring-codesigning.html

**Actual:**

It fails or shows warning during stack deployment since bref layer isn't part of a trusted signing profile.

Lambda layers follow the same signed code package format as function code packages. When you add a layer to a function that has code signing enabled, Lambda checks that the layer is signed by an allowed signing profile. When you enable code signing for a function, all layers that are added to the function must also be signed by one of the allowed signing profiles.

https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/configuration-codesigning.html#config-codesigning-valid

**Possible solution:**

Sign layers during publishing and share aws sigining profile arn so it can be added  to the list of allowed signing profiles during deployment. 
https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/best-practices-and-advanced-patterns-for-lambda-code-signing/
